origin:
68% of all NYC public school students are Black or Latino.

To only have 7 Black students accepted into Stuyvesant (a *public* high school) tells us that this is a system failure.

Education inequity is a major factor in the racial wealth gap. This is what injustice looks like. https://twitter.com/elizashapiro/status/1107744299582660609¬†‚Ä¶

NEWS: Today, seven black students got into Stuyvesant High School, one of the most prestigious public schools in the nation, out of 895 offers. 

The grim statistics will raise pressure on NY's politicians to confront segregation‚Ä¶
replies:
It is called earning it. Stuyvesant has 74 percent Asian students. Do you want more white kids in the school? Your idea is if you cannot earn it you force the school to take unqualified kids.

This is not what injustice looks like. It is what merit looks like.

Your tweet is what myopia looks like.  The problem isn't one school's admissions process, it's the inequal educational opportunities given to the applicants BEFORE they apply. Poor schools get unqualified teachers with high turnover & out of date textbooks
If the majority of admitted students are Asian, are they coming from advanced junior and middle school programs? Instead of discrediting can we uplift those who studied and worked hard?

As someone who comes from the multicultural city of Newark NJ I could tell you that in my experience Asian parents focus more on having their kids study than white, black and Hispanic parents do. We are told to do our best. My Asian friends were told do the best.
Agreed...while there are some parents who not only don‚Äôt give a crap about theirs kids education, they also expect the school to RAISE their child. Don‚Äôt expect education to be handed to you.

I know so many incredibly bright students who would have excelled and thrived in such a rigorous program. But, they could not afford a private tutor or test prep books. This is such a small thing that the NYCDOE can easily step in and make more equitable.
That would be a wise use of taxpayer funds. Kids who want to excel should be given the tools. That is an investment in America.

Absolutely. I volunteered after-school to do SAT prep with our HS students. It‚Äôs a cycle. Lack of resources gets compounded over time. There‚Äôs a disparity in resources and many parents/students don‚Äôt even know to ask/demand better. But those of us who know better should do better
ohheykaila CarmineSabia THensleyRN mfgonzalez24 josh_matera AOC

A lot of these students have parents with degrees, meaning that they can help their kids with homework through most grades. We spend an hour every night doing homework with our kids, they've excelled nicely. I have friends that can't, their kids homework is over their heads.
BeingtheThe ohheykaila CarmineSabia THensleyRN mfgonzalez24 josh_matera AOC

Neither of us spent an hour doing homework with our son for years. He's a 4.0+ student w/o any special tutors, etc...when I was growing up, I had a friend whose parents lacked HS diplomas, we grew up in a  blue collar, coal mining town, He went to Cornell and was a Rhodes Scholar
MrsStigg BeingtheThe CarmineSabia THensleyRN mfgonzalez24 josh_matera AOC

This is a thread about low-income students of color in NYC. You just stated you are a middle-aged white woman from a blue-collar mining town. You don‚Äôt fit the demographic. We‚Äôre also focused on what is happening in NYC currently. How can you not see the flaws in your tweet?
ohheykaila MrsStigg BeingtheThe CarmineSabia THensleyRN mfgonzalez24 josh_matera AOC

White people grow up poor too! It's only sad if a black person doesn't have opportunity. So sick of that crap. We grew our own food, 6 kids, we had nothing growing up. If they were smart they would do better on the testing, I did and I didn't have tutors or special books.
MerlynnSage1 MrsStigg BeingtheThe CarmineSabia THensleyRN mfgonzalez24 josh_matera AOC

No one stated white people cannot grow up in low-income households. The fact of the matter is, people of color in America have a lack of generational wealth due to slavery, Jim Crow, redlining, and other deplorable tactics that were once legal and barred access.
ohheykaila MrsStigg BeingtheThe CarmineSabia THensleyRN mfgonzalez24 josh_matera AOC
She stated it was about black people.
MerlynnSage1 MrsStigg BeingtheThe CarmineSabia THensleyRN mfgonzalez24 josh_matera AOC

@AOC retweeted an article that illuminates the disparity in race of students accepted into elite NYC public schools. That‚Äôs the full extent of the comment. Where did anyone say white people are immune from growing up poor? That never happened. Please be truthful.
ohheykaila MrsStigg BeingtheThe CarmineSabia THensleyRN mfgonzalez24 josh_matera AOC

But the disparity has a false conclusion. Yes disparity, but the reasons are wrong. They say it all the time, you be truthful, Bernie likes to say whites don't know what it's like to be poor. I can tell you are not too bright and not seeing the pic. Critical thinking skills...

It's my opinion that every student who wants an education should have the same right to that education no matter the color of their skin, their religion, or their economic background.  We need to fix this mess, and give everyone a fair chance in America.

Right! Since someone can't pass the high standard, we should lower it. Great way to fix it. I'm not fast enough to qualify for 100 meter in the olympics, so lets everyone run and don't record the time and we all get gold medals. NYC kids have the right to an education already

It is not a out lowering standards. It is a out ensuring that all students have equal access to a quality education. Not all students will rise to the top, but the opportunity should be afforded to all students.

They had an opportunity. did they get denied to take the test? True, not everyone can rise to the top, but SHS are meant for those who do. Nothing stopping a child from doing good and excelling in school. Don't need a SHS to get ahead in life, you need passion and drive.
Poorer schools provide poorer education, resulting in less opportunities for those students. If that's not fixed then there won't be an even playing field.

Sorry, not true in NYC. Schools are what you make of it together with your child. If you believe what you say, then your issue is with the Teachers. 

Also, schools get funded by how many children are in attendance. Not a poorer school, just a poorer school environment.

The majority of public school funding comes from local property taxes. Not from how many people are in the school. The federal govt barely provides any funding to public schools. It literally depends on the housing market. It‚Äôs not a simple fix.

Agreed. Our government has scaled back funding to public schools & mental health funding since the 80's. I remember when California  approved Prop. 8 back in the late 70's; funding dried up, school districts went broke, downsized schools increased class size.
TBudell Masnyk SaveAmericaPle2 pbcdmx EdKrassen AOC

Because the federal government has no business being involved in the educations system. Haven't you noticed how much worse things got after the DOEd was created. We need to get all government out of schools
It should be all about merit. That is true fairness

Imagine two students:

Student A never had to worry about money, has a well funded school, tutors, and their parent paid for test prep.

Student B works part-time, school has little funding, can't afford tutors/test-prep.

Is it fair? No, student A has an advantage.
I think data shows a high portion of Asian students at these high schools come from poor financial backgrounds. The rich ones in NY get sent to private high schools.

Thank you for educating!  Also important to note... despite only representing 15% of kids in the NYC Public School system - more Asian kids chose to take the exam than black and hispanic students, combined.

Lol! The school is only 22% white!

Congratulations, you've played yourself. https://twitter.com/AOC/status/1108020712021868547¬†‚Ä¶
She knows that; she also knows that her marks--I mean, constituents--don't know that.
The sad reality is, Republicans will think 7 students of color is progress.
Since when are Asian-Americans not students of color? I'm all for progressivism but let's not reinvent language to fit ideology.

The issue here is that there is a huge difference in education standards/resources across 5 bouroughs & if city takes steps to bridge that gap, lot more black/Latino kids will get in merit too. Give them equal resources. Merit isn‚Äôt an issue here

It is not resource variations among the boroughs that explains the ‚Äúunder representation‚Äù of certain skin colors. Consider family values and immigrant work ethic as a possible explanation for the  ‚Äúdisproportionate‚Äù Asian student body.  Poor people can earn high test scores too.

Certainly. Cultural differences do make a difference as Asians/South Asians see education as religion. But resources in schools do matter a lot. Many schools have big class sizes, no aids for teachers & sadly lack basic technology. Learning is dependent on latter much more

Most of the Asians kids who got in and who make up the majority of student pop of these elite schools are poor and have the same resources as the other minorities (Latino and black). And they don‚Äôt see education as ‚Äúreligion‚Äù; they value education. 

You just want equal outcome.
guzifer2 NKaur99 DelNorteMiller ChungSports AngelaBelcamino AOC

If everyone‚Äôs complaining about big class sizes now they gonna be in for a surprise at the college level. The parent/kid need to actually want to succeed before anything can happen. Life ain‚Äôt fair, some kids need to work harder than others -________________-
Were they turned down based on the color of their skin or their academic abilities? I have a strong feeling that it‚Äôs the latter.
This is not about stuy's admissions, it's about what is happening before that makes this result possible.

I‚Äôm guessing the ‚Äúbefore‚Äù you‚Äôre talking about is the K through 8 education that prepares (or doesn‚Äôt) kids for high school. That‚Äôs way too late. Minus 9 months to 5 years is the foundation.  If parents (preferably 2) get that right, the rest will follow.

That's not true, schools are the educators.  The onus has to be on them for failing these young people, and on the politicians for cutting education budgets, and for the school board for distributing the funds in a manner that exacerbates the whole problem.

My point is that the fight is mostly won or lost before kids start school. If they don‚Äôt start with the right tools, schools can‚Äôt do much for most.  If there aren‚Äôt books in the home, if they aren‚Äôt read to, aren‚Äôt nurtured, etc., they will likely have limited success in school.
I agree Kurt and that issue needs to be handled upstream thru additional educational resources provided for these kids sooner, and not blame the school for admitting students based on test scores.
Equality of opportunity doesn't mean equality of outcome...

Well said. This is the entire goal of the left.  Hard work should not be required.  That‚Äôs why we have participation trohpies.  We have #GenerationVerukaSalt  who expect to get what they want right now even if they did nothing to earn it #LittleMissMarxist  #PompousLittleTwit pic.twitter.com/PL6BeRyqq5

No..that's not what we want...  Holy crap you people love making straw men out of our very valid arguments.
Your comments literally prove you do not understand systemic racism. It's not your fault it happened but don't act like it's our fault we are here. Wrk tgthr

It‚Äôs the most myopic response to cry ‚Äúsystemic racism‚Äù when a failure is multi varied and complex. ‚ÄúEquity‚Äù programs perpetuate the myth that these communities can‚Äôt thrive without the very system that you claim keeps them from succeeding.
Are you literally making an argument that POC aren‚Äôt making it bc they *inherently* have lower intellect? Wowza.

To be clear I would like for every community to succeed - bar none. In this case there is already a program that takes a look at ‚Äúunderrepresented‚Äù communities and gives spots even when the cutoff is not made. Lowering standards en mass perpetuates cycles of inequality.

Bring back Black families, traditions and entrepreneurship. Group economics which Asians practice. I understand systemic racism and the disadvantage of being disenfranchised however we have to adapt or perish.

The current welfare system as constructed encourages and incentivizes single parent households and rewards additional pregnancies with additional $. There needs to be reform to encourage stronger family units.
This is not true and a continuation of the racist welfare queen myth.
No racism meant. These comments would apply to any race.

I guarantee you most Asian households do not encourage children to watch idiotic TV shows, play video games, use smart phones. They require their children to complete their homework,  read books, learn to play musical instruments. There is discipline, chores, respect at home.

Not sure what you‚Äôre suggesting. This seems to be a blanket statement. My daughter, who is Hispanic, was admitted to a gifted program because of academic achievement. Stuy has always accepted the best of the best. The solution is not quotas, if that‚Äôs your suggestion.
...Because it never happened to me, so it doesn't happen.

You‚Äôre twisting his words. He‚Äôs saying the admission procedure is based on merit and then provided an example. You‚Äôre likely to take the position it‚Äôs based on race, but can‚Äôt provide evidence to support your position.
Thank you for clarifying. That was exactly what I was saying but you see the incendiary responses. Like @AOC is always right and it‚Äôs all premised on systemic racism which simply not true.

This is the direct result of a purposeful state law to limit black/brown kids from populating these schools who at the time was over 50%. The law worked and continues to work: https://www.nytimes.com/1971/05/20/archives/assembly-votes-high-school-curb-limits-city-boards-power-to-ease.html¬†‚Ä¶

Stop perpetuating the code language that K-8 schools are subpar when this test quizzes kids on material that is NOT taught in schools...intentionally. Only way to master the mater is thru test prep. Something that all families can‚Äôt invest in.
it is a math and english entrance exam. I certainly hope that these are being taught in school!
They type of math being covered is NOT taught until later on which is the reason why folks flock to test prep. All tactics that are done intentionally to limit who gets in.
Unless they drastically changed the test, which is certainly possible, when I took it it was everything that I had learned in class -  I never took a single prep course in my life
Not going to question how many yrs ago that was but i will tell you from personal experience with kids, the math is not taught in 8th grade.
well, it WAS a while ago
Preparation for an exam like that starts in preK. If we want more representation in our elite high schools we have to better support those communities early on.

Do you mean explicit exam prep or do you mean general quality education as a form of prep?

Because the former sounds like a problem to me. I would not want kids prepping for an exam 15 years ahead of time or whatever.

I do not mean test prep from preK I mean high quality instruction at community schools. However the group of students that are most prepared start some form of test prep for that exam around 5th grade and take the exam in 8th.

Right . I was conflating the HS placement exams and the SAT for some reason. Oops!

Anyway, even three years is too much. I feel bad for those kids. So much more fun and productive things to do with your time as a kid.
The ‚Äúspecialized‚Äù high schools are not for everyone. They are students that can sink or swim with an intense work load.
Trust me.  The test was the easy part.
Yup I went to Stuy and the test was in fact the easiest part of my whole experience there.
oh I'm sure! I am fairly certain I would not have lasted if I ended up at one!

Think abt what you're saying here. If your argument is that this isn't a systemic issue, the alternative is that you believe black parents care less about their kids.

Unless you can offer another explanation (and I'm willing to hear what you have to say), that's textbook racism.

The foundation of education is fairness, except in America...

America performs worse on education than the rest of the modern nations, and this is part of the reason if someone doesn‚Äôt achieve higher success then it‚Äôs by default that they didn‚Äôt work hard enough instead of actually trying to see why.

Could probably free up resources to help these kids as opposed to funding sanctuary city initiatives...whaddaya think?

This isn‚Äôt a money issue. It‚Äôs a values issue. Education starts at home. It‚Äôs not fair that teachers are expected to teach and parent students. There are many Asians in NYC and they help make up Stuyvesant‚Äôs 74% Asian student body. Values must change and results will follow.
It is a money issue. The only criteria to get into these schools is a test. Kids with more money get very intensive training and coaching.
1/2 of Stuyvesant students are classified as poor by the federal government.

I can tell you from an Asian perspective,  it would be parents and the kids taking the responsibility of that, that's why if you ever dared to put the complete figures, you would know how Asians would be doing better... Don't throw racism card here
Politicians‚Äôs logic: If we cant beat Asian, cancel the game.

Asians have the lowest single parent household rate and highest academic focus culture. I would venture to guess that there were more Asians who applied to this high achievement school than whites, blacks & latinos which would account for the high asian & low black admission.

So, as someone who worked in education, let me ask...
How do we ensure parental involvement, role modeling, etc. in our public schools?  The number one issue I see is a lack of that, which is unfortunately heavily tired to lower incomes as well.  To me, this is a key issue.
Schools should be family community centers. If a parent had a bad school experience they are less likely to become an involved parent.  But if they feel part of a community that will change.

It‚Äôs not just a bad experience though, either.
Many parents are struggling to survive (single parent, low income families) are working much of the time, maybe multiple jobs.
At the poverty line, we also have more at-risk kids from families with drug/alcohol use, or abuse/neglect.

It will require a multifaceted effort that targets families as much as it does education, and we have to realize this is as much a poverty issue as it is a race issue if not more. People in poverty are less likely to to look at high end schools or have transportation resources.

Except a lot of the Asians going to Stuvy come from the same neighborhoods and schools as a lot of the Black and Latino applicants. Do an audit and check for racism, but if it was purely based on merit, let the chips fall where they did.
